Germany HAI burden totals (with 95% uncertainty)

Source: R/bhai_summary.R
bhai_summary.Rd

Format

A data frame with 5 rows (one per HAI type) and 18 columns:

geo

character. Geography label (always "Germany").

sample

character. Data source/sample (always "German PPS").

hai

character. HAI type: HAP, UTI, BSI, SSI, CDI.

cases

numeric. Estimated number of HAIs.

cases_low

numeric. Lower bound of 95\ cases_highnumeric. Upper bound of 95\ deathsnumeric. Estimated attributable deaths. deaths_lownumeric. Lower bound of 95\ deaths_highnumeric. Upper bound of 95\ dalysnumeric. Disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). dalys_lownumeric. Lower bound of 95\ dalys_highnumeric. Upper bound of 95\ yllnumeric. Years of life lost. yll_lownumeric. Lower bound of 95\ yll_highnumeric. Upper bound of 95\ yldnumeric. Years lived with disability. yld_lownumeric. Lower bound of 95\ yld_highnumeric. Upper bound of 95\Zacher et al. (2019) Eurosurveillance. doi:10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.46.1900135bhai_summaryAnnual totals for Germany (German PPS) by HAI type: HAP, UTI, BSI, SSI, CDI. Includes point estimates and 95% uncertainty intervals (UI) for cases, deaths, DALYs, and the DALY components (YLL, YLD).Values mirror the patterns reported in Zacher et al. (2019) and are intended for teaching/demo. See references below for the original study.data("bhai_summary", package = "BHAIBYE") head(bhai_summary)Zacher B., et al. (2019). Burden of healthcare-associated infections in Germany and the EU/EEA. Eurosurveillance, 24(46).datasets
